messageBody:
Chapter 10 does not apply to my problem because its
just about JDBC.

Please consider that we don't use Entity Beans
directly. We use a very unknown (and very bad in my
opinion) framework called JCoffee which uses Entity
Beans (CMP of course) internally.

Since I don't know very much about "native" Entity
Beans, it is maybe hard to describe to you our design.

Okay, I'll read Chapter 11 and come back to you if it
doesn't solve my question.

But can you (or someone else) please tell me this:
- Do you test validation rules with JUnit (such as
maxLength(10))?
- Do you test your Java finder methods (internally EJB
QL, HQL, SQL or whatever)?
- Do you test pre-initializations of business objects
instances (like Article, Customer...)?


--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> haefeleuser wrote:
>
> > Do we do too much testing here? How do you test
> these things? Or don't
> > you test them or only some of them? Is there any
> code example of such
> > a test? What about the finders and the validation
> rules: Do you test them?
>
> DAOs are merely a facade to the persistence
> mechanism. As such, they
> only map data types and construct SQL statements, if
> that. Test that:
> does the DAO properly look up the right EJB in JNDI?
> I recommend having
> a constructor for each DAO that accepts a Context
> which you can fake
> out. In the fake context, put a mock entity bean
> component interface and
> tell it to expect the right method name with the
> right parameters.
>
> Since the persistence mechanism is CMP EJB, test the
> entity beans
> themselves in the container only to the extent
> you're paranoid about CMP
> not working. I don't recommend trying to test your
> bean class with
> fake/mock CMP interfaces. That's painful. You could
> write some tests to
> verify the CMP metadata by merely parsing the
> deployment descriptors.
>
> This is mostly covered in Chapters 10 and 11 of
> _JUnit Recipes_.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
